sen.j: 守護所（しゅごしょ）とは、中世日本において守護が居住した館の所在地のこと。
sen.e: Shogosho is the seat of the castle where Shugo (provincial constable) lived in medieval Japan.
Shogosho is the seat of the castle where Shugo (provincial constable) lived in medieval Japan.
Shogosho was the seat of the castle where Shugo (provincial constable) lived in medieval Japan.

sen.j: 守護の政治的権限の拡大とともに政庁所在地としての機能が国衙より移されていった。
sen.e: With the expansion of political power of Shugo, the functions of Kokuga (provincial government offices) were shifted to Shugosho.
With the expansion of political power of Shugo, the functions of Kokuga (provincial government offices) were shifted to Shugosho.
With the expansion of political power of Shugo, the functions of Kokuga (provincial government offices) were shifted to Shugosho.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期においては、守護の職務は大犯三箇条に限定された。
sen.e: In the early Kamakura period, functions of Shugo were limited to Taibon Sankajo (three major tasks of peacekeeping)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the early Kamakura period, functions of Shugo were limited to Taibon Sankajo (three major tasks of peacekeeping).
In the early Kamakura period, functions of Shugo were limited to Taibon Sankajo (three major tasks of peacekeeping).

sen.j: そして朝廷が任命した国司の政庁がある国衙とは別の場所に置かれるのが一般的であった。
sen.e: Then, Shugosho were placed in different places from Kokuga, where the provincial government offices of Kokuji appointed by the Imperial Court were.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, Shugosho were placed in different places from Kokuga, where the provincial government offices of Kokuji appointed by the Imperial Court were.
Then, Shugosho were placed in different places from Kokuga, where the provincial government offices of Kokushi (provincial governors) appointed by the Imperial Court were.

sen.j: また、守護は世襲ではなく交替制であったため、守護の交代とともに守護所も替わるのが一般的であった。
sen.e: Shugo was not hereditary but shift system, so Shogosho was generally moved according to the change of Shugo.
Shugo was not hereditary but a shift system, so Shogosho was generally moved according to the change of Shugo.
Shugo was not hereditary but a shift system, so Shogosho was generally moved according to the change of Shugo.

sen.j: ところが、鎌倉時代後期以後、守護の職務が治安維持から裁判にまで広がってくるようになると、守護の権威が国司を圧倒するようになる。
sen.e: However, from the late Kamakura period, when functions of Shugo as peace preservation expanded to the administration of justice, authority of Shugo overcame Kokuji.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, from the late Kamakura period, when functions of Shugo as peace preservation expanded to the administration of justice, authority of Shugo overcame Kokuji.
However, from the late Kamakura period, when functions of Shugo as peace preservation expanded to the administration of justice, authority of Shugo overcame Kokushi.

sen.j: そして南北朝時代 (日本)以後には守護が令制国の支配権を得るようになった。
sen.e: Then, after the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), Shugo came to take control of the provinces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, after the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), Shugo came to take control of the provinces.
Then, after the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), Shugo came to take control of the provinces.

sen.j: また、守護の世襲化が進行したこともあり、守護所も固定される傾向が強まった。
sen.e: Also, Shugosho increasingly came to fix in one place according to the development of Shugo's hereditary succession.
Also, Shugosho increasingly became fixed to one place according to the development of Shugo's hereditary succession.
Also, Shugosho increasingly became fixed to one place according to the development of Shugo's hereditary succession.

sen.j: 世襲化した守護の守護所としては当該武家の本拠地、あるいはかつての国衙所在地である府中、その他交通・商業の要所などに置かれるケースが多く見られた。
sen.e: Shogosho for hereditary Shugo were often placed in the home ground of the said samurai family, in Fuchu city, where the seat of the Kokuga was, or in other important spots for transportation or business.
sen.cmt: 府中Fuchuのあとに「City」を補いました
sen.e: Shogosho for hereditary Shugo were often placed in the home ground of the said samurai family, in Fuchu city, where the seat of the Kokuga was, or in other important spots for transportation or business.

Shogosho for hereditary Shugo were often placed in the home ground of the said samurai family, in Fuchu (provincial cities which consist of local governments as the core of the city), where the seat of the Kokuga was, or in other important spots for transportation or business.
sen.cmt: Fuchu city→Fuchuとし、補足追加 (用語集参照)

sen.j: 守護所の固定化によって守護の居館を中心に重臣の居館が配置され、その周辺に市場や寺社などが集まるようになった。
sen.e: Due to fixation of Shugosho, the residences of chief retainers were located centered around the residence of Shugo, then markets and temples and shrines gathered around them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Due to fixation of Shugosho, the residences of chief retainers were located centered around the residence of Shugo, then markets and temples and shrines gathered around them.
Due to fixation of Shugosho, the residences of chief retainers were located centered around the residence of Shugo, then markets and temples and shrines gathered around them.

sen.j: そして地方都市としての役割を果たすようになった。
sen.e: Then, they served as provincial cities.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, they served as provincial cities.
Then, they served as provincial cities.

sen.j: 戦国時代_(日本)に入ると、下剋上による守護大名の没落に伴う新興勢力、あるいは逆に領内支配の確立して守護領国制を脱却した旧守護大名による戦国大名が新たな支配者として浮上する。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), emerging power resulted from the fall of Shugo daimyo (feudal lords) along with gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite), or, on the other hand, the warring loads from old Shugo daimyo, who sloughed off Shugo-ryogoku system (the system that a Shugo dominates a manor) and established the government of the domain appeared as new rulers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the emerging power resulted from the fall of Shugo daimyo (feudal lords) along with gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite), or on the other hand, the warring lords from old Shugo daimyo, who sloughed off the Shugo-ryogoku system (system that a Shugo dominates a manor) and established the government of the domain appeared as new rulers.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the emerging power resulted from the fall of Shugo daimyo (feudal lords) along with gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite), or on the other hand, Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) from old Shugo daimyo, who sloughed off the Shugo-ryogoku system (system that a Shugo dominates a manor) and established the government of the domain appeared as new rulers.
sen.cmt: 統一事項より、the warring lords→Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period)に修正

sen.j: しかし守護所の所在地がそのまま本拠地として用いられたケースもあった。
sen.e: However, some seats of Shugosho were still used as their home ground.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, some seats of Shugosho were still used as their home ground.
However, some seats of Shugosho were still used as their home ground.
